these radios I have here on on the screen just like this radio here that I have in my hand um they have all that stuff that I
just described in the previous software defined radio it can receive all these uh signals from the air and you can tune
it and everything uh but they also have circuitry to decode the information you receive so receive a signal there's
noise there's signal you want to get the signal out and you need to decode it turn it into audio or or data or
whatever and so these radios here have a conventional radio have circuitry that
does that a software defined radio does not have that stuff and so it is simpler
there's less going on instead of having this physical device here which admittedly is half battery um you can
have this little tiny device here and so you can see there's significant size difference there's just less stuff in
the software defined radio than there is in a physical in a and more conventional radio so it's a regular radio but with

reporting system aprs is um it's an extension of
packet radio and packet radio used a protocol called
ax25 which is just amateur x25 anyone here uh familiar with x25 as a
networking protocol anyone old enough to remember that that's probably the question right um so x25 was turned into ax25 to do
packet radio over the Internet so you could establish I you could establish connections and you can run an entire TCP IP stack on top of it uh now in
practice establishing those connections is brittle it's at 12200 B so it's really slow and um it in it just wasn't
used that often uh the the fun thing about it is is that where instead of having a MAC address to identify your
network card use your call sign that uniquely identifies you but aprs was
sort of the simplification of the ax25 where they got rid of the whole idea of trying to establish a connection and
instead you use this protocol to just send bursts of information out to announce things and so you can for example assign
that to well I I got a slide talking about the things you can announce with it so people will put it on their

they can also be picked up by repeaters and so uh the way this works is that uh part of
the message is is a path or a sort of a there's a counter in that message that
says how many times to repeat it so if I send a message out i' say repeat this twice and then a repeater picks it up
and says okay I'm going to send it out again and I'm going take that number two make it a one and then the next one says
I picked this up I'm going to repeat it one more time and then it doesn't get repeated after that this allows you to
get your packets of information your broadcasts Over the Horizon because this is all line of
sight and so you can build little data networks this way but the most interesting part of APs is it's not only

the case of reddis uh that ID is made up of two parts the first part is the time
stamp in milliseconds that the message was received you can do this manually if you want I don't
recommend it and a sequence number in case you get more than one message a millisecond which uh you will probably
see when we start running this and then as these events come in they just start stacking
up and so we get a history of all the events that come in from whenever it's started to whenever you're done it's
